awd_titl_txt: GEOPRISMS Postdoctoral Scholar proposal: Unravelling monogenetic volcanism in the Cascades Volcanic Range
awd_abstract_narration:
Globally almost 1 billion people live in areas subject to volcanic hazards. In North America, the most populated region subject to significant volcanic hazards is the Pacific Northwest. Although the hazards associated with larger stratovolcanoes such as Mount St Helens and Mount Hood are reasonably well understood, a less studied type of volcano are the so call "monogenetic" centers, smaller volcanic cones that are widely distributed throughout the region. These typically consist of a small volcanic cone and associated lava fields. The amount of material erupted is typically less than a cubic kilometer total erupted volume, although larger examples also occur. However, within the Cascade Volcanic Range, there are thousands of this type of volcanic edifice. Their wide geographic distribution and overall short eruptive life span mean that the locations and effects of future eruptions are different to stratovolcanoes, and are more difficult to predict. Most monogenetic systems have not been studied in significant detail to predict future eruption behavior. This project seeks to gain greater understanding of the subsurface magmatic processes associated with monogenetic volcanism in the relatively populous Central Oregon region of the Cascades. In particular, the project will focus on the speed and style of magma movement through the volcanic edifice during eruptions, using a range of petrological and geochemical techniques. The project includes the training of a postdoctoral investigator.

The project will focus on a number of monogenetic centers in the Central Oregon area, including some related to Newberry Volcano (e.g. Lava Butte) and from the MacKenzie Pass area (Collier Cone, Little Belknap Crater). For the selected volcanoes zoned crystals, melt inclusions and melt embayments will be studied for diffusion chronometry of major elements, trace elements and volatile species analysis (CO2, H2O) to constrain the time between initiation of volcanic unrest and eruption to the surface. Magma ascent rates will also be calculated based on depth estimates from melt inclusions. The goal is to constrain the time between when a new eruption may be detected using remote means (typically seismic studies) and when actual eruptions might commence. Studies of melt inclusion and crystal compositions will also allow insight into the chemical and petrological complexity and structure of monogenetic magma plumbing systems. Overall the results of this work will significantly improve knowledge of subduction-related monogenetic volcanism and the hazard response required for these centers - a hitherto less well studied type of volcanism. Evaluating eruption style (effusive vs explosive) and ascent rates from volatile analysis, together with calculated diffusion chronometry timescales, will give new insight into monogenetic volcanism in a well characterized subduction zone system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to gain a greater understanding of so called "monogenetic" volcanoes in the Central Oregon part of the Cascade Range. These are smaller volcanoes that occur as scattered smaller craters and other volcanic vents across central Oregon and other parts of the Cascade subduction zone. The eruptions of these type of volcanoes are typically short lived, and the location of the next eruption will occur is not well known. This is in contrast to the more well-known central volcanoes like Mount Hood and Mount St Helens. 

We have studied several monogenetic and related volcanoes by examining erupted lavas and other materials samples from these volcanoes and making a detailed set of chemical measurements. We also used models of the rate of element diffusion in crystals to assess how long crystals have been stored in different samples.  We studied samples from Belknap Crater, Collier Cone, and Four in One Cone in Central Oregon, from cinder cones associated with Newberry volcano, and Paint Pot Crater from Medicine Lake volcano in Northern California. Our goal was to examine the magmatic processes which lead to eruptions and to estimate the time that occurs between this initiation and the arrival of magma at the surface. This time frame is important because it provides an estimate of the time that we would have to respond for a future eruption once we detected that activity was occurring underground (via earthquakes, gas releases and other remote means of detection), and when hazards such as lava flows, tephra releases would occur. 

Our results suggest that a period of weeks to months likely occurs between the magmatic events that initiate a new eruption underground and the arrival of magma at the surface. In addition, we found that many of the systems we studies showed a much great complexity of magmatic processes than normally considered likely for this type of volcano - which are often considered to be relatively simple and short lived. This includes mixing of different composition batches of magma, formation of different populations of crystals, and melting and assimilation of rocks from the surrounding crust. We also used measurements of carbon dioxide and water in glass and small bubbles trapped in crystals to produce the best estimate to date of the depths at which crystals form and are stored beneath Paint Pot Crater - our data suggests this occurs about ~5-10 kilometers (3-6 miles) below the surface.
